name: Vitamin D3

effects.summary: Reduces fracture risk, especially in deficient individuals over 50. Strong evidence from multiple large RCTs.

dosage.notes: Higher end (4000 IU) if deficient; 1000-2000 IU for maintenance

citations.title: IOM Dietary Reference Intakes for Calcium and Vitamin D
Vitamin D supplementation and fracture risk meta-analysis

effects.summary: Reduces fall risk in elderly populations, particularly those with vitamin D deficiency.

dosage.notes: 800-1000 IU/day shown most effective for fall prevention

citations.title: Fall prevention with supplemental and active forms of vitamin D: a meta-analysis

effects.summary: Reduces risk of acute respiratory infections, especially in those with deficiency (<25 nmol/L).

dosage.notes: Daily or weekly dosing more effective than bolus doses for immune benefits

citations.title: Vitamin D supplementation to prevent acute respiratory tract infections: systematic review and meta-analysis

effects.summary: May reduce depressive symptoms, with each additional 1000 IU/day yielding SMD of -0.32. Effects strongest in deficient individuals.

dosage.notes: Short-term supplementation (≤8 weeks) may produce stronger effects

citations.title: Meta-analysis of the effect of vitamin D on depression

effects.summary: May enhance muscle strength, particularly in deficient individuals and athletes.

dosage.notes: Most benefit in those with baseline deficiency

citations.title: Effects of vitamin D3 supplementation on strength in athletes: meta-analysis of RCTs

effects.summary: May improve HbA1c and fasting blood sugar in type 2 diabetes patients, with modest effect sizes.

dosage.notes: Benefits most pronounced in vitamin D deficient diabetic patients

citations.title: Effect of vitamin D supplementation on glycemic control and cardiovascular risk factors in T2DM: meta-analysis

safety.upper_limit: 4000 IU/day (UL per IOM; some evidence supports up to 10,000 IU safely)

form_notes: D3 (cholecalciferol) preferred over D2. Take with fat for absorption. 1 mcg = 40 IU.

name: Magnesium

effects.summary: Statistically significant reductions in both systolic and diastolic BP, with greater benefit in hypertensive individuals. Umbrella meta-analysis of 10 meta-analyses confirms effect.

dosage.notes: Glycinate or citrate forms preferred for bioavailability. Split into 2 doses.

citations.title: Impact of magnesium supplementation on blood pressure: umbrella meta-analysis of RCTs

effects.summary: Improves subjective sleep quality, especially in older adults and those with insomnia. May reduce sleep onset latency.

dosage.notes: Take glycinate or threonate form 30-60 min before bed

citations.title: The effect of magnesium supplementation on primary insomnia in elderly: a double-blind placebo-controlled clinical trial

effects.summary: Reduces frequency of muscle cramps, particularly in pregnant women and exercise-related cramps.

dosage.notes: Citrate form may help if constipation is also an issue

citations.title: Magnesium for muscle cramps: systematic review

effects.summary: May reduce subjective anxiety, especially in those with mild-to-moderate anxiety and magnesium deficiency.

dosage.notes: Glycinate form may have calming advantage due to glycine content

citations.title: The role of magnesium in neurological disorders

effects.summary: Reduces CRP and oxidative stress markers. Meta-analysis of 28 studies showed significant effects on TAC, MDA, GSH, and CRP.

dosage.notes: Any well-absorbed form (glycinate, citrate, malate)

citations.title: Magnesium supplementation on oxidative stress and inflammation: systematic review and meta-analysis

effects.summary: Reduces migraine frequency and severity. Recognized by AAN as 'probably effective' for migraine prevention.

dosage.notes: Oxide or citrate most studied for migraine; may take 3 months for full effect

citations.title: Evidence-based guideline update: pharmacologic treatment for episodic migraine prevention in adults (AAN)

safety.upper_limit: 350 mg/day supplemental (from supplements only; no UL for dietary magnesium)

form_notes: Glycinate: best absorbed, least GI issues, calming. Citrate: good absorption, mild laxative. Oxide: cheap but poorly absorbed. Threonate: may cross BBB (cognitive claims). Malate: good for energy/muscle.

name: Omega-3 (EPA/DHA Fish Oil)

effects.summary: Consistently and significantly reduces triglycerides by 15-30% in a dose-dependent manner.

dosage.notes: 2-4g EPA+DHA for therapeutic triglyceride reduction; 1g for general health

citations.title: Effect of omega-3 fatty acids on cardiovascular outcomes: systematic review and meta-analysis of 38 RCTs

effects.summary: Associated with reduced cardiovascular mortality. EPA monotherapy shows greater risk reductions than EPA+DHA combined.

dosage.notes: AHA recommends 1-2g EPA+DHA/day for secondary prevention

citations.title: Effect of omega-3 fatty acids on cardiovascular outcomes: meta-analysis of 38 RCTs

effects.summary: Reduces inflammatory markers including CRP, IL-6, and TNF-alpha. Effects most pronounced at higher doses.

dosage.notes: Higher EPA ratio may be more anti-inflammatory

citations.title: Omega-3 fatty acids and inflammatory processes: from molecules to man

effects.summary: EPA-predominant formulations show significant antidepressant effects as adjunct therapy. DHA alone less effective.

dosage.notes: EPA ≥60% of total omega-3 most effective for depression

citations.title: Omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids in prevention and treatment of mood disorders: review

effects.summary: Reduces joint pain and morning stiffness in rheumatoid arthritis. May reduce NSAID use.

dosage.notes: May take 2-3 months for full anti-inflammatory effect on joints

citations.title: A meta-analysis of the analgesic effects of omega-3 PUFAs in inflammatory joint pain

effects.summary: DHA important for brain development and may slow cognitive decline. Evidence mixed for established dementia.

dosage.notes: DHA is the primary structural omega-3 in the brain

citations.title: Docosahexaenoic acid and cognition throughout the lifespan

safety.upper_limit: 5000 mg EPA+DHA/day generally well tolerated; FDA considers up to 3g/day as GRAS

form_notes: Triglyceride form better absorbed than ethyl ester. Take with meals containing fat. Algal oil is vegan alternative (mainly DHA). Store in cool/dark place to prevent oxidation.

name: Creatine Monohydrate

effects.summary: Consistently increases muscle strength and power output during resistance training. One of the most well-researched supplements.

dosage.notes: 3-5g/day maintenance dose. Optional loading phase: 20g/day for 5-7 days.

citations.title: Effects of creatine supplementation and resistance training on muscle strength gains: systematic review and meta-analysis

effects.summary: Increases lean body mass when combined with resistance training. Significant effects in both young and older adults.

dosage.notes: Best results when combined with resistance training

citations.title: Impact of creatine supplementation and exercise training in older adults: meta-analysis

effects.summary: Enhances high-intensity, short-duration exercise performance (sprints, weightlifting). Well-established ergogenic aid.

dosage.notes: Timing not critical; consistent daily intake most important

citations.title: Effects of creatine supplementation on performance and training adaptations

effects.summary: May improve short-term memory and reasoning, particularly under stress, sleep deprivation, or in vegetarians/vegans who have lower baseline creatine stores.

dosage.notes: Vegetarians/vegans may see greater cognitive benefit

citations.title: Effects of creatine monohydrate supplementation on cognitive function in adults: systematic review and meta-analysis

effects.summary: Some evidence that creatine plus resistance training may improve bone mineral density in older adults, but results are mixed.

dosage.notes: Must combine with resistance training for potential bone benefits

citations.title: Impact of creatine supplementation and exercise training in older adults: meta-analysis

safety.upper_limit: No established UL; 3-5g/day used safely in studies up to 5 years

form_notes: Monohydrate is the most studied and cost-effective form. No advantage to other forms (HCl, buffered, etc.). Mix in water or any beverage. Micronized form dissolves better.

name: Vitamin B12

effects.summary: Essential for preventing and treating B12 deficiency, which causes megaloblastic anemia, neuropathy, and cognitive decline. Oral, sublingual, and IM routes all effective.

dosage.notes: 250-1000 mcg/day for vegans/vegetarians; 1000 mcg/day for deficiency correction. Methylcobalamin or cyanocobalamin both effective.

citations.title: Efficacy of different routes of vitamin B12 supplementation: systematic review and network meta-analysis

effects.summary: Corrects fatigue and low energy when caused by B12 deficiency. No benefit for fatigue in B12-replete individuals.

dosage.notes: 500-1000 mcg/day; check B12 levels first

citations.title: Effects of vitamin B12 supplementation on cognitive function, depressive symptoms, and fatigue: systematic review and meta-analysis

effects.summary: Reduces elevated homocysteine levels, especially when combined with folate. High homocysteine is a cardiovascular risk marker.

dosage.notes: 500-1000 mcg/day, often combined with folate and B6

citations.title: Homocysteine-lowering by B vitamins: meta-analysis

effects.summary: Prevents and may reverse peripheral neuropathy caused by B12 deficiency. Early treatment critical.

dosage.notes: 1000 mcg/day oral or IM injections for established neuropathy

citations.title: Vitamin B12 deficiency: recognition and management

safety.upper_limit: No established UL; B12 has very low toxicity even at high doses
common_side_effects: rare; occasional skin reactions with injections

form_notes: Methylcobalamin and cyanocobalamin are both effective. Sublingual and oral routes comparable to IM for most people. Vegans should supplement daily.

name: Iron

effects.summary: Standard treatment for iron-deficiency anemia. Effectively raises hemoglobin and ferritin levels.

dosage.notes: Every-other-day dosing may improve absorption and reduce side effects. Take on empty stomach with vitamin C.

citations.title: Daily vs non-daily oral iron supplementation for iron deficiency anemia: meta-analysis of RCTs

effects.summary: Reduces fatigue even in non-anemic iron-deficient individuals (ferritin <30 ng/mL). Significant improvements in anxiety, fatigue, and physical wellbeing.

dosage.notes: Check ferritin levels first; supplement only if deficient

citations.title: Efficacy of iron supplementation on fatigue and physical capacity in non-anaemic iron-deficient adults: systematic review and meta-analysis

effects.summary: Improves intelligence and short-term memory scores in iron-deficient children, adolescents, and menstruating adults.

dosage.notes: Dose depends on age; supplement only in iron-deficient individuals

citations.title: Psychiatric and cognitive outcomes of iron supplementation in non-anemic children and menstruating adults: meta-analysis

effects.summary: Improves exercise capacity and VO2max in iron-deficient athletes, particularly female endurance athletes.

dosage.notes: Screen athletes for iron deficiency; ferritin <30 warrants supplementation

citations.title: Iron supplementation and physical capacity in iron-deficient adults

safety.upper_limit: 45 mg/day elemental iron (NIH UL for adults)

form_notes: Ferrous bisglycinate (chelated) best tolerated. Ferrous sulfate cheapest but more GI side effects. Take with vitamin C to enhance absorption. Avoid taking with calcium, tea, or coffee. Every-other-day dosing may improve absorption.

name: Zinc

effects.summary: Zinc lozenges reduce cold duration by ~33-37% in adults when started within 24h of symptom onset. Cochrane 2024 review confirms treatment benefit.

dosage.notes: Zinc acetate or gluconate lozenges; take every 2-3 hours while awake. Start within 24h of symptom onset.

citations.title: Zinc for prevention and treatment of the common cold (Cochrane Review)

effects.summary: Supports immune cell function and reduces infection risk in zinc-deficient populations, particularly elderly and children in developing countries.

dosage.notes: 15-30 mg/day for immune maintenance; higher doses only short-term for acute illness

citations.title: Zinc and the immune system

effects.summary: May restore testosterone levels in zinc-deficient males. No benefit in zinc-replete individuals.

dosage.notes: Only beneficial if zinc deficiency is present

citations.title: Zinc status and serum testosterone levels of healthy adults

effects.summary: Oral zinc reduces inflammatory acne lesion count by approximately 50% in several trials.

dosage.notes: Zinc gluconate 30mg most studied for acne; use for 2-3 months

citations.title: Zinc and acne: a systematic review

safety.upper_limit: 40 mg/day (NIH UL for adults)
common_side_effects: copper depletion with chronic high doses

form_notes: Picolinate and citrate well-absorbed. Gluconate and acetate lozenges for colds. Long-term supplementation >40mg/day should include copper (2mg) to prevent depletion. Take with food to reduce nausea.

name: Vitamin C

effects.summary: Regular supplementation reduces cold duration by 8% in adults and 14% in children. Does not prevent colds. Greater benefit in physically active individuals.

dosage.notes: Must be taken regularly (prophylactically) — not effective when started after cold onset

citations.title: Vitamin C for preventing and treating the common cold (Cochrane)

effects.summary: Supports various cellular functions of both innate and adaptive immune system. Deficiency impairs immunity.

dosage.notes: 200mg/day sufficient to saturate plasma levels in healthy adults

citations.title: Vitamin C and immune function

effects.summary: Enhances non-heme iron absorption by 2-3x when taken together. Important for vegetarians and those with iron deficiency.

dosage.notes: Take 100-200mg vitamin C with iron supplement to enhance absorption

citations.title: Iron absorption: the role of ascorbic acid

effects.summary: Major water-soluble antioxidant that protects against oxidative stress. May reduce biomarkers of oxidative damage.

dosage.notes: Smokers need 35mg/day more than non-smokers

citations.title: Vitamin C and immune function

effects.summary: Essential cofactor for collagen synthesis. Higher intakes associated with better skin appearance and wound healing.

dosage.notes: Topical vitamin C also beneficial for skin

citations.title: The roles of vitamin C in skin health

safety.upper_limit: 2000 mg/day (NIH UL)
common_side_effects: increased kidney stone risk at very high doses

form_notes: Ascorbic acid is the standard form. Buffered forms (sodium ascorbate) easier on stomach. Liposomal vitamin C may have higher bioavailability. Split doses >500mg for better absorption.

name: Fiber (Psyllium Husk)

effects.summary: Reduces LDL cholesterol by 5-10% as adjunct to statin therapy or alone. FDA-approved health claim for heart disease risk reduction.

dosage.notes: 7-10g/day most effective; split into 2-3 doses before meals. Must drink plenty of water.

citations.title: Psyllium supplementation and lipid profiles: systematic review and dose-response meta-analysis

effects.summary: Reduces postprandial blood glucose and HbA1c when taken before meals. Gel-forming property slows carbohydrate absorption.

dosage.notes: Take 5g before meals; most effective when taken 15 min before eating

citations.title: Psyllium effects on metabolic parameters: meta-analysis

effects.summary: Highly effective bulk-forming laxative. Increases stool frequency and improves stool consistency.

dosage.notes: Start low (3g) and increase gradually. Always take with full glass of water.

citations.title: Psyllium fiber for GI health: review

effects.summary: Recommended by ROME Foundation as only fiber with evidence for IBS. Gel-forming property distinguishes it from insoluble fiber which may worsen IBS.

dosage.notes: Start low and increase slowly to avoid bloating

citations.title: Psyllium: the gel-forming nonfermented fiber for IBS (ROME Foundation)

safety.upper_limit: No established UL; doses up to 30g/day used in studies
common_side_effects: choking risk if taken without enough water

form_notes: Take with at least 8oz water — expands 10-14x in volume. Space 2 hours from medications. Start with small dose and increase over 1-2 weeks. Whole husk or powder both effective.

name: Probiotics

effects.summary: Certain multi-strain probiotics reduce global IBS symptoms. Combination of Bifidobacterium and Lactobacillus strains show best evidence. Strain-specific effects.

dosage.notes: 1-10 billion CFU/day. Multi-strain formulations (Bifidobacterium + Lactobacillus) most evidence. Strain matters more than dose.

citations.title: Efficacy of probiotics in IBS: systematic review and meta-analysis

effects.summary: Saccharomyces boulardii and Lactobacillus rhamnosus GG reduce risk of antibiotic-associated diarrhea by ~50%.

dosage.notes: Start with antibiotics and continue 1-2 weeks after. S. boulardii or L. rhamnosus GG preferred.

citations.title: Probiotics for the prevention of antibiotic-associated diarrhea (Cochrane)

effects.summary: May reduce duration and severity of upper respiratory infections. Effects are strain-specific.

dosage.notes: 1-10 billion CFU/day of multi-strain formulations

citations.title: Probiotics and upper respiratory tract infections: meta-analysis

effects.summary: May improve gut barrier function and reduce inflammation in various GI disorders. Umbrella meta-analysis supports use in multiple GI conditions.

dosage.notes: 10-50 billion CFU/day; strain selection important for specific conditions

citations.title: Probiotics and gastrointestinal disorders: umbrella meta-analysis

safety.upper_limit: No established UL; high doses generally well tolerated

form_notes: Strain specificity matters — different strains for different conditions. Look for third-party tested products with specific strain designations (e.g., LGG, BB-12). Refrigerated products not necessarily better. Fermented foods also provide probiotics.

name: Melatonin

effects.summary: Reduces sleep onset latency (time to fall asleep) significantly. Effect peaks at 2-4 mg/day. Meta-analysis of 26 RCTs confirms benefit.

dosage.notes: 0.5-3mg typically sufficient; take 30-60 min before desired bedtime. Higher doses not more effective.

citations.title: Optimizing time and dose of melatonin as a sleep-promoting drug: systematic review and meta-analysis of 26 RCTs

effects.summary: Modestly increases total sleep time. Effect is smaller than sleep onset improvement.

dosage.notes: Extended-release formulations may help more with total sleep time

citations.title: Melatonin for sleep: systematic review and meta-analysis

effects.summary: Highly effective for reducing jet lag symptoms when timed correctly. Take at destination bedtime.

dosage.notes: Take at destination bedtime for 2-5 nights after arrival; 0.5-5mg effective

citations.title: Melatonin for prevention and treatment of jet lag (Cochrane)

safety.upper_limit: No established UL; 0.5-5mg generally recommended. Higher doses (10mg+) not more effective.

form_notes: Less is more — 0.5-1mg often as effective as 5-10mg. Immediate-release for sleep onset issues; extended-release for sleep maintenance. Take 30-60 min before bed in dim light.

name: Ashwagandha

effects.summary: Significantly reduces anxiety on Hamilton Anxiety Scale and other measures. Non-linear dose-response with favorable effects at moderate doses.

dosage.notes: KSM-66 (300-600mg) or Sensoril (125-250mg) standardized extracts most studied

citations.title: Does ashwagandha supplementation have a beneficial effect on anxiety: meta-analysis

effects.summary: Significantly reduces serum cortisol levels. Effects consistent across multiple RCTs.

dosage.notes: KSM-66 300mg twice daily commonly studied

citations.title: Effects of ashwagandha supplements on cortisol, stress, and anxiety levels: meta-analysis

effects.summary: Improves sleep quality and sleep onset latency, particularly in those with insomnia.

dosage.notes: Take in the evening for sleep benefits

citations.title: Efficacy and safety of ashwagandha root extract on insomnia and anxiety: RCT

effects.summary: May modestly increase testosterone in males, particularly under stress or during resistance training.

dosage.notes: KSM-66 extract most studied for testosterone effects

citations.title: Effects of ashwagandha on reproductive hormone levels in adult males

effects.summary: May improve strength output and VO2max when combined with training. Effects modest.

dosage.notes: Take for at least 8 weeks for exercise performance benefits

citations.title: Examining the effect of ashwagandha on muscle strength and recovery: RCT

safety.upper_limit: No established UL; up to 600mg/day root extract used in most studies

form_notes: Use standardized root extracts: KSM-66 (full-spectrum root) or Sensoril (root + leaf). Cycle 2 months on, 2 weeks off. May stimulate thyroid — monitor if thyroid issues.

name: Collagen Peptides

effects.summary: Improves skin elasticity, hydration, and reduces wrinkles. Meta-analysis of 26 RCTs (1721 participants) confirms benefits.

dosage.notes: 5-10g/day of hydrolyzed collagen peptides; effects seen after 4-12 weeks

citations.title: Effects of oral collagen for skin anti-aging: systematic review and meta-analysis of 26 RCTs

effects.summary: Reduces joint pain and improves function in osteoarthritis. May also reduce activity-related joint pain in athletes.

dosage.notes: 10g/day most commonly studied for joints; type II collagen (40mg/day UC-II) for OA specifically

citations.title: Collagen supplementation for osteoarthritis: meta-analysis

effects.summary: Preliminary evidence that collagen peptides may improve bone mineral density in postmenopausal women.

dosage.notes: 5g/day specific collagen peptides (e.g., FORTIBONE) studied for bone

citations.title: Specific collagen peptides increase bone mineral density in postmenopausal women with osteopenia: RCT

effects.summary: May improve nail growth rate and reduce brittleness. Limited but positive evidence.

dosage.notes: 2.5g/day bioactive collagen peptides studied

citations.title: Oral supplementation with specific bioactive collagen peptides improves nail growth

safety.upper_limit: No established UL; up to 15g/day well tolerated in studies

form_notes: Hydrolyzed collagen peptides (type I/III) for skin and general use. Type II (UC-II) for joint health (40mg/day). Marine collagen may have better absorption. Mix powder in coffee, smoothies, or water. Take with vitamin C for collagen synthesis.

name: CoQ10

effects.summary: Improves ejection fraction and reduces major adverse cardiovascular events in heart failure patients. Q-SYMBIO trial showed mortality benefit.

dosage.notes: 200-300mg/day in divided doses for heart failure; 100mg/day for general use

citations.title: Role of CoQ10 in cardiovascular disease treatment: 2024 systematic review and meta-analysis

effects.summary: Significantly reduces systolic and diastolic blood pressure. 2024 meta-analysis confirmed significant improvement.

dosage.notes: 100-200mg/day; takes 4-12 weeks for blood pressure effects

citations.title: Effects of CoQ10 on blood pressure and heart rate in adults: meta-analysis

effects.summary: May reduce statin-associated myopathy/muscle pain. Statins deplete CoQ10 levels. Evidence mixed but plausible mechanism.

dosage.notes: 100-200mg/day ubiquinol form; trial for 2-3 months

citations.title: Effects of CoQ10 supplementation on statin-induced myalgia: meta-analysis

effects.summary: May reduce migraine frequency. Small trials show promising results but evidence limited.

dosage.notes: 200-300mg/day; may take 3 months for full migraine prevention effect

citations.title: Coenzyme Q10 as a migraine preventive

effects.summary: May improve sperm quality and egg quality (ovarian reserve) through antioxidant mechanisms. Preliminary evidence.

dosage.notes: 200-600mg/day for fertility; start 2-3 months before conception attempt

citations.title: CoQ10 supplementation and fertility outcomes: review

safety.upper_limit: No established UL; up to 1200mg/day used in clinical studies safely

form_notes: Ubiquinol (reduced form) better absorbed than ubiquinone, especially in older adults. Take with fat-containing meals. Body's natural CoQ10 production declines with age. Essential for mitochondrial energy production.

name: Curcumin / Turmeric

effects.summary: Reduces CRP, IL-6, and other inflammatory markers. Meta-analysis confirms anti-inflammatory effects across multiple conditions.

dosage.notes: Use bioavailability-enhanced forms (with piperine, phospholipid, or nanoparticle formulations)

citations.title: Antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects of curcumin/turmeric supplementation: meta-analysis

effects.summary: Reduces pain and improves function in osteoarthritis, comparable to NSAIDs in some studies. Reduces WOMAC scores.

dosage.notes: Bioavailability-enhanced forms (Meriva 500mg, Theracurmin 180mg) most effective

citations.title: Efficacy of turmeric extracts and curcumin for alleviating symptoms of joint arthritis: meta-analysis of RCTs

effects.summary: May reduce depressive symptoms, particularly as adjunct to antidepressants. Effects may be mediated by anti-inflammatory action.

dosage.notes: 500-1000mg/day bioavailability-enhanced curcumin for mood

citations.title: Curcumin for the treatment of major depression: meta-analysis of RCTs

effects.summary: Reduces MDA and increases TAC and SOD levels. Beneficial for improving oxidative stress biomarkers.

dosage.notes: Must use bioavailability-enhanced form; standard turmeric powder has <5% curcumin

citations.title: Effects of curcumin on biomarkers of oxidative stress: meta-analysis of RCTs

safety.upper_limit: No established UL; up to 8g/day curcuminoids used in short-term studies

form_notes: Standard curcumin has very poor bioavailability (~1%). Must use enhanced forms: with piperine (20x increase), phospholipid complex (Meriva, 29x), or nanoparticle (Theracurmin, 27x). Take with fat. Not the same as turmeric spice.

name: Berberine

effects.summary: Reduces fasting blood glucose and HbA1c comparably to metformin in some trials. Activates AMPK pathway. Strong evidence from systematic reviews.

dosage.notes: 500mg 2-3x/day with meals. Start at 500mg/day and increase gradually.

citations.title: Efficacy and safety of berberine on components of metabolic syndrome: systematic review and meta-analysis

effects.summary: Reduces LDL cholesterol and triglycerides. Upregulates LDL receptors in the liver via a different mechanism than statins.

dosage.notes: 500mg 2-3x/day; can be combined with statins (consult physician)

citations.title: Berberine and metabolic syndrome components: meta-analysis

effects.summary: Modest reductions in BMI and waist circumference. May reduce visceral fat.

dosage.notes: 500mg 3x/day with meals

citations.title: Berberine effects on body composition: meta-analysis

effects.summary: Modulates gut microbiome composition and reduces TMAO levels. Downregulates TMAO-mediated ER stress pathway.

dosage.notes: GI side effects common initially; start low

citations.title: Berberine's impact on health: comprehensive review

safety.upper_limit: No established UL; 1500mg/day commonly used in studies

form_notes: Berberine HCl most common form. Poor bioavailability improved by dihydroberberine (DHB) form. Take with meals to reduce GI side effects. Split into 2-3 daily doses. May interact with many drugs — consult pharmacist.

name: NAC (N-Acetyl Cysteine)

effects.summary: Precursor to glutathione, the body's master antioxidant. Effectively raises glutathione levels and reduces oxidative stress markers.

dosage.notes: 600mg 1-3x/day; most studies use 600-1200mg/day

citations.title: N-Acetylcysteine: impacts on human health

effects.summary: Mucolytic properties help thin mucus in chronic bronchitis and COPD. Reduces exacerbation frequency.

dosage.notes: 600mg 2x/day for respiratory conditions

citations.title: High-dose NAC in COPD: meta-analysis

effects.summary: Standard treatment for acetaminophen overdose. Supports liver detoxification and glutathione repletion. May benefit NAFLD.

dosage.notes: 600-1200mg/day for liver support; much higher IV doses for acetaminophen OD

citations.title: NAC for liver health: review

effects.summary: Emerging evidence for OCD, trichotillomania, substance use disorders, and as adjunct in psychiatric conditions. Modulates glutamate.

dosage.notes: 1200-2400mg/day in divided doses for psychiatric applications

citations.title: NAC in psychiatric conditions: review

effects.summary: May reduce exercise-induced oxidative damage and improve recovery. Typical dose in studies is 5.8g/day but range varies widely.

dosage.notes: Evidence mixed; may blunt some training adaptations

citations.title: Performance and side effects of NAC supplementation: systematic review and meta-analysis

safety.upper_limit: No established UL; 600-1800mg/day commonly used; higher doses under medical supervision

form_notes: Oral capsules most common. Has a strong sulfur smell. Take on empty stomach or with food if nausea occurs. May be taken with vitamin C to enhance effects. FDA has debated its status as a supplement vs drug.

name: Vitamin K2

effects.summary: Activates osteocalcin for calcium deposition in bones. Meta-analysis shows K2 supplementation improves BMD, particularly at lumbar spine.

dosage.notes: MK-7: 100-200mcg/day; MK-4: 15-45mg/day. MK-7 has longer half-life. Synergistic with vitamin D3.

citations.title: Effects of vitamin K supplementation on bone mineral density at different sites: meta-analysis

effects.summary: Activates matrix Gla protein (MGP) which inhibits arterial calcification. Adequate K2 intake associated with less coronary calcification.

dosage.notes: MK-7: 100-200mcg/day. Important when supplementing vitamin D3 and/or calcium.

citations.title: Menaquinone-7 supplementation improves arterial stiffness: RCT

effects.summary: MK-4 (45mg/day) reduces fracture risk in Japanese postmenopausal women. MK-7 at lower doses also shows bone benefits.

dosage.notes: MK-4: 45mg/day (pharmacological dose); MK-7: 100-200mcg/day (nutritional dose)

citations.title: Vitamin K and fracture risk: meta-analysis

safety.upper_limit: No established UL for vitamin K2
common_side_effects: very rare; generally very well tolerated

form_notes: MK-7 (from natto) preferred over MK-4 — longer half-life, lower effective dose. Often paired with vitamin D3. Take with fat for absorption. Critical if supplementing vitamin D3 and/or calcium to direct calcium to bones rather than arteries.

name: Folate / Methylfolate

effects.summary: Prevents neural tube defects (spina bifida, anencephaly) when taken before and during early pregnancy. One of the most well-established supplement benefits.

dosage.notes: 400-800mcg/day folic acid; start at least 1 month before conception. 4mg/day if prior NTD pregnancy.

citations.title: IOM Dietary Reference Intakes for Folate

effects.summary: Prenatal folate-containing multivitamins reduce rates of various congenital anomalies beyond neural tube defects.

dosage.notes: 400-800mcg/day as part of prenatal vitamin

citations.title: Prenatal multivitamin supplementation and rates of congenital anomalies: meta-analysis

effects.summary: May enhance antidepressant efficacy as adjunct therapy. L-methylfolate may be more effective in MTHFR variants.

dosage.notes: 7.5-15mg L-methylfolate/day as adjunct to antidepressant (prescription form: Deplin)

citations.title: Folate supplementation as adjunct treatment in relieving depressive symptoms: umbrella meta-analysis

effects.summary: Folate is the primary nutrient for reducing elevated homocysteine levels. Combined with B12 and B6 for maximal effect.

dosage.notes: 400-800mcg/day folic acid or equivalent methylfolate; combine with B12 and B6

citations.title: Homocysteine-lowering by B vitamins: meta-analysis

safety.upper_limit: 1000 mcg/day folic acid (can mask B12 deficiency); no UL for food folate or L-methylfolate
common_side_effects: generally well tolerated; rare GI upset

form_notes: L-methylfolate (5-MTHF) is the active form — preferred for those with MTHFR variants. Folic acid is cheaper and well-studied for pregnancy. Food folate from leafy greens and legumes.

name: Calcium

effects.summary: Calcium plus vitamin D modestly improves BMD and reduces fracture risk. Benefits clearest in those with low dietary calcium.

dosage.notes: 500-600mg per dose max for absorption. Total intake (diet + supplement) should reach 1000-1200mg/day.

citations.title: Effects of combined calcium and vitamin D supplementation on BMD: meta-analysis

effects.summary: Calcium + vitamin D reduces fracture risk, particularly in institutionalized elderly.

dosage.notes: Combined with 800-1000 IU vitamin D for fracture prevention

citations.title: Meta-analysis of calcium supplementation for prevention of fractures

effects.summary: 1000-1200mg/day calcium reduces PMS symptoms including mood, bloating, and cramps.

dosage.notes: 1200mg/day most studied for PMS; effects seen within 2-3 cycles

citations.title: Calcium carbonate and the premenstrual syndrome

safety.upper_limit: 2500 mg/day (NIH UL for adults 19-50); 2000 mg/day for 51+
common_side_effects: possible cardiovascular risk at high doses

form_notes: Citrate better absorbed, can take without food. Carbonate cheapest, must take with food. Dietary calcium preferred. Always pair with vitamin D3 and K2.

name: Selenium

effects.summary: Reduces TPO antibodies in Hashimoto's thyroiditis after 3+ months.

dosage.notes: 200mcg/day selenomethionine most studied; supplement for at least 3 months

citations.title: Clinical efficacy of selenium supplementation in patients with thyroid disease: meta-analysis

effects.summary: Supports selenoprotein function important for immune response. Benefits mainly in selenium-deficient populations.

dosage.notes: 55-200mcg/day; avoid exceeding 400mcg/day

citations.title: Selenium and immune function: review

effects.summary: Essential cofactor for glutathione peroxidase enzymes.

dosage.notes: 55-100mcg/day sufficient; selenomethionine preferred

citations.title: Selenium in health and disease: review

safety.upper_limit: 400 mcg/day (NIH UL)

form_notes: Selenomethionine most bioavailable. Brazil nuts are richest food source (~70-90mcg per nut). Do NOT exceed 400mcg/day — narrow therapeutic window.

name: Iodine

effects.summary: Essential for thyroid hormone synthesis. Deficiency causes goiter and hypothyroidism. Supplementation only needed if deficient.

dosage.notes: 150mcg/day RDA for adults; 220mcg/day in pregnancy; 290mcg/day in lactation.

citations.title: Effects of iodine supplementation on thyroid function: systematic review and meta-analysis

effects.summary: Iodine deficiency during pregnancy causes cretinism and cognitive impairment. Adequate iodine critical for fetal brain development.

dosage.notes: 220mcg/day during pregnancy; most prenatal vitamins contain 150mcg

citations.title: Iodine supplementation in pregnancy: systematic review

safety.upper_limit: 1100 mcg/day (NIH UL for adults)

form_notes: Iodized salt provides ~45mcg per 1/4 tsp. Kelp supplements vary widely — risk of excess. Potassium iodide more reliable. Most needed by vegans and pregnant women.

name: Boron

effects.summary: May support bone health by influencing calcium and magnesium metabolism. Reduces urinary calcium excretion.

dosage.notes: 3-6mg/day most studied; no established RDA

citations.title: Nothing boring about boron: review

effects.summary: May increase free testosterone and reduce SHBG. Limited evidence from small studies.

dosage.notes: 6-10mg/day studied for testosterone effects; limited evidence

citations.title: Plasma boron and effects of boron supplementation in males

effects.summary: Epidemiological evidence suggests areas with higher boron intake have lower arthritis rates. Limited clinical data.

dosage.notes: 6mg/day used in arthritis studies

citations.title: Boron and arthritis: review

safety.upper_limit: 20 mg/day (IOM UL for adults)

form_notes: Available as boron citrate, boron glycinate. No established RDA. Average dietary intake is 1-3mg/day from fruits, vegetables, nuts, and legumes.

name: L-Theanine

effects.summary: Promotes relaxation without sedation. Increases alpha brain waves. Effective for situational anxiety.

dosage.notes: 100-200mg for acute stress; 200-400mg/day for ongoing anxiety. Often combined with caffeine.

citations.title: Examining the effect of L-theanine on sleep: systematic review

effects.summary: May improve sleep quality by promoting relaxation. Not a sedative — works by reducing anxiety that interferes with sleep.

dosage.notes: 200-400mg 30-60 min before bed

citations.title: Effects of L-theanine on sleep outcomes: systematic review and meta-analysis

effects.summary: Combined with caffeine, improves attention and task switching. Reduces caffeine jitteriness while maintaining alertness.

dosage.notes: 100-200mg L-theanine + 50-100mg caffeine is the most studied nootropic combination

citations.title: L-theanine and caffeine combination improves cognitive performance

safety.upper_limit: No established UL; doses up to 900mg/day used in studies
common_side_effects: very rare; headache, dizziness at high doses

form_notes: Found naturally in green tea (~25mg per cup). Suntheanine is a patented pure L-isomer form. Works synergistically with caffeine (2:1 ratio theanine:caffeine). Effects within 30-60 minutes.

name: Glycine

effects.summary: Improves subjective sleep quality and next-day alertness. Lowers core body temperature facilitating sleep onset.

dosage.notes: 3g before bed is the standard studied dose; dissolves easily in water (slightly sweet)

citations.title: Glycine ingestion improves subjective sleep quality

effects.summary: Major amino acid in collagen (33%). Supplementation may support collagen production with vitamin C.

dosage.notes: 3-10g/day; combine with vitamin C and proline for collagen support

citations.title: Glycine and collagen synthesis: review

effects.summary: May improve insulin sensitivity and reduce HbA1c. Stimulates GLP-1 secretion.

dosage.notes: 3-5g/day; preliminary evidence

citations.title: Glycine supplementation in metabolic syndrome: review

safety.upper_limit: No established UL; doses up to 15g/day used in studies
common_side_effects: very rare; mild GI upset possible at high doses

form_notes: Powder dissolves easily, tastes slightly sweet. Can add to water or tea before bed. Also found in bone broth and gelatin. Calming NMDA receptor activity.

name: Electrolytes (Sodium/Potassium)

effects.summary: Sodium supplementation during prolonged exercise maintains plasma volume and improves endurance. Critical during heavy sweating.

dosage.notes: 300-600mg sodium per hour during prolonged exercise (>60 min).

citations.title: Electrolyte supplementation during exercise: systematic review

effects.summary: Electrolytes improve fluid retention and prevent hyponatremia during high fluid intake or heavy sweating.

dosage.notes: For keto/fasting: 3-5g sodium, 1-3g potassium, 300-400mg magnesium daily.

citations.title: Fluid and electrolyte needs for exercise: review

effects.summary: Sodium and potassium may reduce exercise-associated muscle cramps, though evidence is mixed.

dosage.notes: Sodium: 500-1000mg before exercise; Potassium: from food/supplement

citations.title: Electrolytes and exercise-associated muscle cramps

safety.upper_limit: Sodium: 2300mg/day general population. Potassium: no UL but OTC limited to 99mg/dose.

form_notes: Commercial mixes (LMNT, Liquid IV) convenient but expensive. DIY: 1/4 tsp salt + lite salt (KCl) + magnesium in water. Most important during keto/low-carb, fasting, heavy exercise, or hot weather.

name: Protein (Whey/Plant)

effects.summary: Whey protein + exercise significantly enhances muscle protein synthesis. Most well-studied protein supplement.

dosage.notes: 20-40g per serving; total daily protein target: 1.6-2.2g/kg body weight.

citations.title: Whey protein supplementation combined with exercise on muscle protein synthesis: meta-analysis

effects.summary: Protein supplementation during resistance training increases strength gains. Effective across ages.

dosage.notes: Total daily protein intake matters more than timing or source

citations.title: Whey protein supplementation on muscle strength and physical performance: meta-analysis

effects.summary: High protein increases satiety, preserves lean mass during weight loss, and modestly increases thermogenesis.

dosage.notes: Target 25-30% of calories from protein for weight management

citations.title: The role of protein in weight loss and maintenance

effects.summary: Protein supplementation with exercise helps prevent age-related muscle loss in older adults.

dosage.notes: Older adults need 30-40g/serving for maximal MPS stimulation

citations.title: Protein supplementation to prevent sarcopenia: review

safety.upper_limit: No established UL; up to 2.2g/kg/day well-studied

form_notes: Whey isolate: highest quality, fast absorbing, low lactose. Casein: slow-release (good before bed). Plant-based (pea + rice blend): comparable to whey. Leucine content matters most (~2.5g per serving).

name: Caffeine

effects.summary: Well-established ergogenic aid. Increases time to exhaustion and power output in both endurance and strength activities.

dosage.notes: 3-6mg/kg body weight, 30-60 min before exercise. Lower doses (1-3mg/kg) also effective.

citations.title: Effects of caffeine on endurance running performance: meta-analysis

effects.summary: Improves alertness, reaction time, and cognitive performance, especially under sleep deprivation.

dosage.notes: 75-150mg typical effective dose; equivalent to 1-2 cups coffee

citations.title: Caffeine and cognitive performance: review

effects.summary: Increases metabolic rate by 3-11% and enhances fat oxidation. Effect attenuates with chronic use.

dosage.notes: Cycling may maintain metabolic benefits

citations.title: Normal caffeine consumption: influence on thermogenesis and daily energy expenditure

safety.upper_limit: 400 mg/day for healthy adults (FDA); 200mg/day during pregnancy

form_notes: Coffee: ~95mg per 8oz cup. Caffeine pills cheapest pure form. Half-life 5-6 hours — avoid within 8-10 hours of bedtime. Combines well with L-theanine.

name: Prenatal Multivitamin

effects.summary: Folic acid-containing prenatals reduce neural tube defects by 50-70%.

dosage.notes: Should contain at least 400mcg folic acid. Start 1-3 months before conception.

citations.title: Prenatal multivitamin supplementation and congenital anomalies: meta-analysis

effects.summary: Reduces rates of cardiac defects, cleft palate, limb deficiencies, and urinary tract defects.

dosage.notes: Complete prenatal with iron, folate, DHA, iodine, choline

citations.title: Prenatal vitamins and congenital anomalies: meta-analysis

effects.summary: Prevents iron deficiency anemia, associated with preterm birth and low birth weight.

dosage.notes: 27mg iron/day recommended in pregnancy

citations.title: Iron requirements in pregnancy: guideline

effects.summary: DHA supports fetal brain and eye development. Iodine supports thyroid function critical for cognitive development.

dosage.notes: 200-300mg DHA/day; prenatal should also include 150mcg iodine and 450mg choline

citations.title: Evidence based recommendations for optimal prenatal supplement

safety.upper_limit: Follow individual nutrient ULs; prenatals are formulated within safe ranges

form_notes: Key nutrients: folate (400-800mcg, methylfolate preferred), iron (27mg), DHA (200-300mg), iodine (150mcg), choline (450mg ideal). Gummy prenatals often lack iron and iodine. Start 1-3 months before conception.

name: Saw Palmetto

effects.summary: Earlier studies showed benefit for BPH symptoms, but large rigorous RCTs (NEJM 2006) showed no significant difference vs placebo. Some meta-analyses still show modest IPSS improvements.

dosage.notes: 320mg/day liposterolic extract (85-95% fatty acids/sterols). May take 4-6 weeks.

citations.title: Saw palmetto for BPH (NEJM RCT)
Saw palmetto for BPH: systematic review and meta-analysis

effects.summary: May have mild 5-alpha reductase inhibition (anti-DHT). Very limited evidence — much weaker than finasteride.

dosage.notes: 320mg/day; evidence very weak compared to finasteride or minoxidil

citations.title: Finasteride vs saw palmetto in androgenetic alopecia

safety.upper_limit: No established UL; 320mg/day is standard therapeutic dose

form_notes: Liposterolic extract (85-95% fatty acids) is the studied form — not raw berry powder. Evidence weaker than prescription medications (tamsulosin, finasteride) for BPH.
